title-group.article-title: ATOB algorithm: an automatic ontology construction for Thai legal sentences retrieval

author-notes.corresp: Nuanwan Soonthornphisaj, Department of Computer Science, Faculty of Science, Kasetsart University, Bangkok, Thailand. Email: fscinws@ku.ac.th

abstract.p: Ontology plays an important role in knowledge representation, especially in the domain of information retrieval. However, building ontology remains a challenging problem because it is a time-consuming task for experts. To overcome these drawbacks, we propose a novel approach called the Automatic Thai Legal Ontology Building (ATOB) algorithm for automatic legal ontology building and to improve the court sentences retrieval process. The ATOB can automatically generate seed ontology and expand the ontology using Thai legal terminology, i.e. TLlexicon. The expansion process is terminated automatically by the threshold parameter. Moreover, the ATOB applies the concept of the ant colony algorithm to improve the court sentences retrieval process. We conclude that the effective ontology should be weight-embedded. The empirical results demonstrate that the performance of the ATOB algorithm is better than that of the traditional search method. The performance figures for the ATOB framework measured in terms of precision, recall, F-measure and diversity are 0.90, 0.91, 0.90 and 0.39, respectively.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Ontology can be used as a knowledge representation technique in the specific domain of a conceptualization [1]. It is widely used in the crucial role to improve the performance of the retrieval process. Currently, there are many specific domain ontologies such as breast cancer ontology [2], agriculture-specific ontology [3], e-learning ontology [4], etc. Several legal ontologies have been constructed such as legal ontology for the Spanish e-government [5], documentary ontology of French law dedicated to information retrieval on the web [6], etc. However, for the Thai law, we have not had any ontology for law users. Therefore the Supreme Court sentences retrieval process cannot provide results to users. Studying Thai law needs Supreme Court sentences as a set of precedent cases to fulfil legal knowledge. The Supreme Court of Thailand has provided the keyword-based or the traditional search engine as a service to lawyers, legal students, judges and law researchers. Another advantage of Thai law ontology is that users can understand the overview of main legal knowledge concepts obtained from the ontology. These main concepts help self-study users to gain complete legal knowledge in the domain of specific law.
We propose a new algorithm called ATOB to tackle this problem to improve the court sentences retrieval process and enhance the ontology building method. The ATOB algorithm consists of six modules:

list-item.p: Documents pre-processing – used for filtering the completed sentences.
Legal term frequency pre-processing – used for finding the legal term frequency of each sentence.
TLlexicon pre-processing – obtained from a law expert.

Automatic seed ontology building – responsible for constructing seed ontology by randomly select Supreme Court sentences. Then, this module performs word segmentation and finds their relationship using TLlexicon. Note that the TLlexicon is Thai legal terminology which consists of Thai legal terms and their related terms (see Table 3). The TLlexicon covers two datasets of Thai civil Supreme Court sentences: Thai succession law and family law.
Legal document retrieval – complies with the concept of the ant colony algorithm [7] to do weighted ontology for the relevant legal documents.

Legal ontology expansion – ontology expansion using the TLlexicon dictionary. While the ontology is expanded, the process can be terminated automatically using the threshold parameter. The threshold value is the ratio between the total number of first-level child nodes of the keyword from ontology and the total number of first-level child nodes of the keyword from TLlexicon. The ontologies can be applied to the retrieval algorithm, which is suitable for the Supreme Court sentences search engine.

sec.p: This article is organized as follows. Section 2 describes the overview of research works related to legal ontology. In Section 3 we propose our innovative framework and a new algorithm for ontology building in order to enhance the retrieval performance. Section 4 contains the experimental results and discussion. Finally, we give a summary and consider future research directions.

sec.title: 2. Related works
sec.p: This article addresses the problem of ontology building and documents retrieval process. For more than a decade, ontologies have been developed for knowledge systems. In this section, we present the selection of research works related to ontology construction. Section 2.1 briefly introduces the concept of ontology construction methodology. Our previous work on TLOE I and TLOE II is described in Sections 2.2 and 2.3.

sec.title: 2.1. Ontology construction methodology
sec.p: Nowadays, the dictionary and thesaurus are widely used in ontology building to create a domain concept. For instance, a machine-readable dictionary (MRD) is used for an initial legal ontology refinement using a statistical analysis method. This method is given to refine the legal ontology, based on the comparison between the initial legal ontology and the best MRD correspondences to given legal concepts [8]. Furthermore, a novel bilingual ontology was constructed using WordNet and the Chinese Classified Thesaurus (CCT). This technique was built from existing knowledge and semantic information using the support vector machines (SVM) method and a lattice algorithm for aligning and merging the knowledge bases [9]. Moreover, the specific domain dictionary can be created by a domain expert and applied to ontology construction. The Korean classifier was constructed from Korean WordNet and large corpora such as newspapers, textbooks, scientific papers and law documents. Korean classifier ontology consisted of semantic hierarchies and the relations of classifiers [10]. The product ontology system of the Korean Government was constructed using a technical dictionary [11]. In addition, ThaiLegalWordNet is a Thai legal terminology created by a law expert that consists of legal terms and their related terms. The Thai law dictionary is used for ontology building using the expansion process [12]. However, taxonomy and a lexicon were applied for ontology construction. For example, the Thai agriculture ontology concepts and taxonomic relations used for automatic ontology building were extracted by the lexicon and co-occurrence features from Thai agricultural corpora [13]. Finally, a new interesting method for ontology construction is a core ontology or seed ontology. Core ontology extracted from Spanish privacy law, which consists of concepts and relations, is used for Spanish ontology building [14], whereas Thai legal ontology is constructed by the ontology expansion function using a seed ontology created by a law expert [15]. Furthermore, the Thai legal seed ontology is automatically created by the ATOB algorithm and used for automatic legal ontology construction [16].

In legal knowledge, ontology was applied to several legal applications. For example, ontology of the Spanish privacy norm is constructed and applied to the preservation of citizens’ privacy using a location based services (LBS) system [14]. In order to improve the management of copyright in the internet, known as digital rights management, ontology is used for copyright framework development on semantic web ontology. Altogether, the core copyright concepts were modelled for the content operation [17]. Moreover, core law ontology is performed in law domains, e.g. the e-court European project of Dutch criminal law [18]. The construction method of legal application ontology is based on the merging of micro-ontologies extracted from European community directives. The TERMINAE method enhanced micro-ontology building using an alignment process with a core legal ontology [19]. The e-commerce system converted an expert system on the United States’ law governing the sale of goods from the uniform commercial code (UCC) into a knowledge-based system using the web ontology language (OWL) [20]. The software was built to support the user in order to refine legal ontology based on MRD, and worked in international sale of goods contracts [8]. Furthermore, the ontology framework is used to improve the querying of relevant judgments based on domain knowledge [21]. The IT support for junior judges was improved by legal ontologies using an intelligent FAQ system. The system emphasizes the importance of professional knowledge and their experience as an important pillar for constructing the ontology [22]. The METHONTOLOGY methodology is used for ontology building in the legal domain. The ontology is extracted from existing class taxonomy and adapted to the Spanish legal domain [23].

sec.title: 2.2. The TLOE I system
sec.p: The TLOE I system is a framework of Thai law ontology building. It consists of an ontology expansion method and the ant colony algorithm in order to improve the court sentences retrieval process. The corpus of the TLOE I system consists of 781 Thai succession law sentences published in 1997–2009. There are 220 legal terms and 424 relationships in the Thai legal dictionary ThaiLegalWordNet created by a law expert. First of all, TLOE I used 19 nodes and 18 links as a seed ontology obtained from a legal expert. The initial ontology can be expanded by ontology expansion module using ThaiLegalWordNet.

Twenty-six legal users obtain a set of keywords. Each user (ant) arbitrarily selects the keyword and chooses a set of suggestion words (query expanded term) obtained from the query expansion process. Then, the pheromone level of the path between the keyword and the chosen term(s) will be accumulated. On the other hand, the pheromone level will be evaporated from the path between the keyword and the ignored term(s) [7]. The ontology expansion module is performed until the first-level child nodes of the keyword are completed, and then the process is terminated.

As a result, we conducted an experiment to see the efficiency of the ant colony and we found that this could be used to enhance the performance of the retrieval process. It infers that the pheromone level affects retrieval performance. The drawback of the TLOE I algorithm is that it uses a manual seed ontology created by a legal expert and the expansion process needs too much computational time since the process is terminated after the first-level child nodes of the keyword are completed [12].

sec.title: 2.3. The TLOE II system
sec.p: The TLOE II framework consists of TLOE I and an automatic-stop ontology expansion module for the query expansion enhancement. The corpus of TLOE II consists of 1303 sentences related to Thai succession law and family law published from 1997 to 2009. Moreover, this corpus consists of 126,996 terms obtained from a word segmentation process. There are 282 main legal terms and 551 relationships in ThaiLegalWordNet. The seed ontology of succession law consists of 19 nodes and 18 links. The initial family law ontology has seven nodes and six links. Each seed ontology is expanded by an ontology expansion process which is continued until the number of first-level child nodes of the keyword is greater than or equal to the threshold value, after which the function is terminated. Note that the threshold parameter is calculated as the total number of first-level child nodes of the keyword from the ontology divided by the total number of first-level child nodes of the keyword from ThaiLegalWordNet.

The contributions of TLOE II are the concise ontology size and the less computational time. It provides a promising result in terms of retrieval performance. We found that TLOE I and TLOE II have similar efficiencies from the user’s point of view even if they have different ontology size and total processing time [15]. However, the TLOE II method uses a manual seed ontology, which makes it an expensive and time-consuming task for domain experts.

sec.title: 3. The structure of ATOB
sec.p: To overcome the weaknesses of TLOE I and TLOE II, we propose in this article a framework called ATOB, which includes six processes: documents pre-processing, legal term frequency pre-processing, TLlexicon pre-processing, automatic seed ontology building, legal document retrieval and legal ontology expansion.

Figure 1 illustrates our framework. The Thai Legal Corpus is obtained from two processes: documents pre-processing and legal terms frequency pre-processing. Documents pre-processing is used for filtering completed sentences, and consists of document number, decision contents and sections (Table 1). Legal terms frequency pre-processing is used for preparing all legal term frequencies for each judgment. Moreover, TLlexicon pre-processing is embedded in the Thai Legal Lexicon. This dictionary, obtained from a law expert, consists of legal terms and their relationships. Additionally, the automatic seed ontology building module is used for automatic seed ontology creation. The legal document retrieval module applied the ant colony algorithm to the relevant documents from the retrieval process. Moreover, the legal ontology expansion module is used for the ontology expansion process. The module can be terminated automatically using the threshold parameter.

sec.title: 3.1. Documents pre-processing
sec.p: The Thai Legal Corpus was extracted from the Thai Supreme Court sentences version 1.6 for PC (DEKA 2007) that was collected by the Information Technology and Communication Center, Supreme Court of Thailand and the Supreme Court search engine website (www.supremecourt.or.th). We obtained 110,982 original Thai Supreme Court sentences in total from two resources published from 1928 to 2009. The 5101 completed court sentences were extracted from the original court sentences published from 1997 to 2009 and covered Thai civil and commercial law. In this process, all completed court sentences were prepared and stored in database format. This process is embedded in the Thai Legal Corpus procedure (see Figure 1).

Table 1 illustrates the important fields of each sentence in the Thai Legal Corpus. The docno is the sentence number, which derives from dkyear and dknum. The text includes all decision contents from the judges and the section is the section number(s) stated in the code law. The last parameter, recall, represents the relevant document status. This parameter depends on the section of each sentence. If at least one section of the sentence is between 1435 and 1755, indicating that the document is about Thai civil and commercial laws, the recall parameter is equal to 1 and it means that this sentence is a relevant document. On the other hand, if the sentence is not a relevant document, the recall value is equal to 0.

Consider a set of examples in Table 1: the docno number 255205690 combines the dkyear number 2552 and the dknum number 5690. The final judgment content is ‘การที่โจทก์จำเลยจดทะเบียนหย่ากันเพื่อประโยชน์ในการเสียภาษี …’ (the plaintiff and the defendant got divorced for tax benefits …) as shown in text. This sentence was justified according to section number 155 and 193/6. The recall is equal to 0 because the section number is not in our scope. So, this sentence is not a relevant document. On the other hand, the recall parameter of sentence number 255204921 is equal to 1 since three sections of this sentence are in our scope. Consequently, this sentence is a relevant document.

sec.title: 3.2. Legal term frequency pre-processing
sec.p: We obtained a set of Thai legal terms from TLlexicon dictionary. There are 159 legal terms covering two Thai civil law domains: succession law and family law. Each legal term of each sentence was counted using the WordSegmentation function and stored the legal term frequency in database format. We found 658,457 legal terms from all completed court sentences in our corpus. Table 2 shows examples of the frequency of each legal term in a sentence. The docno parameter refers to the decision number, and all legal terms and their frequencies are displayed in database format. This database is used for calculating the total score of the sentence (DocScore function) in the LegalDocRetrieval module (see more detail in Section 3.5).

sec.p: For instance, the frequencies of legal terms in document number 255202220 are as follows: ครอบครัว (family) 66, พินัยกรรม (will) 3, มรดก (succession) 12, สมรส (marriage) 5, ทรัพย์ (property) 9 and หมั้น (engage) legal terms 0.

sec.title: 3.3. TLlexicon pre-processing
sec.p: TLlexicon is a set of Thai legal terminology constructed by law experts who extracted the legal terms from Supreme Court sentences, final judgements, civil and commercial code, decisions or their experience. TLlexicon covers two Thai civil law domains, which are succession law and family law. There are 159 concepts and 825 relationships. Moreover, the TLlexicon is designed for adding new legal terms by the legal experts in the future. The TLlexicon dictionary is used in the seed ontology building process and the ontology updating process (see Figure 1).

The specific domain dictionary consists of a set of legal terms and their relationships called Superclass. For ease of presentation, we use simple and small legal terms: the ครอบครัว (family) node and the มรดก (succession) node have the same Superclass called ‘Thing’. Note that, Thing is the root node of our ontology. Moreover, the ครอบครัว (family) node is the Superclass node of both the สมรส (marriage) node and the หมั้น (engage) node. Additionally, the พินัยกรรม (will) node is a child node of the มรดก (succession) node, as shown in Table 3.

sec.title: 3.4. The automatic seed ontology building module
sec.p: We propose a module for automatic seed ontology construction in order to spare experts on the bulk of the job. First of all, this process is started automatically and seed ontology created using a set of random sentences and the TLlexicon dictionary. Normally, the seed ontology consists of the Thing node.

Given a set of sentences in Thai Legal Corpus, 50 court sentences are randomly selected by the RandomDoc process. Next, the first selected sentence is loaded and each legal term is extracted using the WordSegmentation procedure. Then, the Superclass term of each term is explored from the TLlexicon using the Explore function. If the Superclass term is Thing or a node in the seed ontology, this node will be connected to the ontology using the JoinConcept function. When the OntologyExpanded function returns true, the meaning is that the seed ontology can be constructed. Next, the automatic seed ontology building process will be terminated and the seed ontology will be used in the Thai Legal Ontology as an initial ontology. On the other hand, if the OntologyExpanded function returns false, it means that the first random sentence cannot create seed ontology. After that, the next selected sentence will be loaded and all systems will restart (see Table 4).

caption.p: Automatic Seed Ontology Building algorithm

sec.p: Given a list of randomly selected sentences (Table 2) and TLlexicon (Table 3), we found that the first document cannot be used to create seed ontology because it contains no term with Superclass in the current ontology. On the contrary, the seed ontology was constructed by the second document because it has the Thing node as the Superclass term of ครอบครัว (family) and มรดก (succession). As a result, the example of our seed ontology is formed using all nodes and their relationships as shown in Figure 2.

caption.p: Example of seed ontology and three kinds of node in the ontology.

sec.p: We stored three parameters in the path between the keyword and their expanded term(s). This technique is more flexible than our previous technique, which stored all parameters directly in the node. There are three kinds of nodes in the ontology: a root, branch and leaf (see Figure 2). Each node consists of the name of the legal term, and each path is attached with the pheromone level (ph), and count and weight parameters (see Table 5 for more detail). Moreover, we store the ontology structure in XML format (see Figure 3), which supports the JoinConcept process in Table 4 and OntologyTraversal in Table 6.

sec.title: 3.5. The legal document retrieval module
sec.p: In the context of document retrieval, we propose a legal document retrieval module for the court sentences retrieval improvement using weighted ontology. First of all, this process obtains the seed ontology from the automatic seed ontology building module. Then, the ontology is used in the query expansion process, whereas the ant colony algorithm is applied for the weighted ontology. The retrieved sentences are not only returned to the user but also used in the legal ontology expansion module.

We simulate the concept of the ant colony in the query expansion process, i.e. finding the shortest path between food and nest. The mission of each ant (user) is to find the food (relevant documents). Each ant leaves the pheromone while it moves on the shortest path (chosen path): the pheromone of the chosen path is increased but that of the ignored path decreases as time passes because of evaporation [7].

Considering Table 6, this process is started when 26 ants (legal users) randomly enter a set of keywords to the legal document retrieval module. The SearchConcept function is performed to traverse through the ontology and find the target node. If the node is found in the ontology, the algorithm determines the type of node whether it is a root or a branch node (see Figure 2). Then the algorithm explores the path(s) attached between the keyword node and all the first-level child nodes. After that, all the first-level child nodes are proposed to the user using the OntologyTraversal function. The user may select the query expansion term(s) that relate to the user requirement from the proposed terms using the ChosenTerm procedure. In the case that no matched term is found in the ontology, the terms variable will contain the original keyword only.

sec.title: 3.6. Legal ontology expansion module
sec.p: A new methodology is proposed for automatic ontology expansion using three data sources: the seed ontology obtained from the Thai Legal Ontology, the TLlexicon and a list of retrieved documents called LegalDocRanked obtained from the Legal document retrieval module. The legal terms are extracted from the first document of the LegalDocRanked and used for the ontology expansion process by the Ontology Updating function (see Figure 1). This process is terminated automatically using the threshold parameter.

Through the following example, if termi cannot be found in the ontology, our algorithm will traverse the TLlexicon and obtain its Superclass. After that, the Superclass is explored in the ontology again. Finally, if the Superclass is found in the ontology, termi can immediately be connected to the ontology (see Figure 4). For example, the term ‘G’ in Figure 4 cannot be found in the original ontology; the algorithm explores the TLlexicon and finds that the Superclass of ‘G’ is ‘C’, so node ‘G’ is connected to node ‘C’.

caption.p: Example of ontology expansion.

sec.p: Table 8 shows the OntologyExpansion module, which obtains a set of retrieved sentences called LegalDocRanked from the previous module. The status parameter is the percentage of the total number of first-level child nodes of the keyword in the ontology and the total number of first-level child nodes of the keyword in TLlexicon. The threshold parameter is set to 0.8. This means that the ontology can be expanded until the keyword has 80% of the total first-level child nodes.

caption.p: Ontology Expansion algorithm

tr.td: Input: LegalDocRanked ←{Doc1, Doc2,…, Docn} Ontology, status

sec.p: In the case of the status parameter of the keyword being <0.8, the first document list from the LegalDocRanked will be loaded and the WordSegmentation function is performed to extract legal terms. Each legal term is explored in the TLlexicon dictionary for their Superclass. Then both the legal term and its Superclassi are traversed in the ontology again. If the NotFoundLink function returns true, it means that the legal term and its Superclass are not joined together in the ontology. After that, two terms will be connected by the JointConcept function. Finally, if the JointConcept function is done, this means that the ontology can be expanded or the OntologyExpanded function returns true. Next, the ontology expansion process is terminated and immediately returns the updated ontology to the Thai Legal Ontology corpus.

On the other hand, if the status parameter of the keyword is ≥0.8, the ontology expansion process will be ignored. Moreover, if the NotFoundLink function returns false, it means that both the legal term and its Superclass are already in the ontology. If none of the legal terms extracted from the first document can be used for expanding the ontology, the JointConcept function returns false. Then the second document is loaded and the processes repeated.

sec.title: 4.1.1. The seed ontology created by ATOB algorithm1.1.1
sec.p: The RandomDoc function is used for randomly selecting 50 sentences from the Thai Legal corpus. Then the WordSegmentation process is used for extracting the Thai legal terms from the first random document. After that, the ATOB algorithm uses the Automatic seed ontology building module for creating seed ontology. However, if the first document cannot create seed ontology, the next list of random documents is loaded and tried.

The ATOB algorithm has the ability to create seed ontology of succession law and family law as shown in Figure 5. There are six nodes and five relationships (the initial parameter of seed ontology is shown in Table 9).

sec.title: 4.2. Results
sec.p: In order to evaluate the performance of the ATOB algorithm, a set of keywords consisting of eight legal terms: หย่า (divorce), ผู้สืบสันดาน (descendant), ผู้จัดการมรดก (property manager), พินัยกรรม (will), สมรส (marriage), ทายาท (heir), มรดก (succession) and บุตร (child) are given to 26 law experts. Each expert randomly picks up the keywords and the ATOB algorithm is applied.

As can be seen in Table 11, we study the efficiency of each technique in order to find the appropriate method. We explore the performance in three aspects: seed ontology construction, ant colony algorithm and ontology expansion module. The seed ontology created by the ATOB system is called the Automatic technique and the seed ontology manually built by the expert is called Manual technique. Furthermore, the ant colony algorithm is embedded in the Weight Updating process (see Figure 1) for improving the retrieval process, and called the With ant technique. In the case of the Without ant technique, the Weight Updating process is ignored and the phUpdate, countUpdate and weightUpdate functions (see Table 6) are also ignored. Moreover, the ontology expansion process is divided into two techniques: the system can be terminated automatically using the threshold parameter (the Automatic-stop technique), and the expansion process is terminated when the first-level child nodes of the keyword are completed (the Non-automatic-stop technique).

caption.p: Experimental setup

sec.p: We set up nine experiments to evaluate the performance of the ATOB algorithm in different aspects. As shown in Table 11, we investigate the appropriate method of seed ontology construction (Automatic vs Manual). The effects of the ant colony algorithm (With ant vs Without ant) were examined among these experiments. Furthermore, the ontology expansion process is evaluated to compare between algorithms with automatic and non-automatic stops.
The performances are measured using precision, recall, F-measure and diversity value in equations (5)–(8), respectively:

Precision is the number of relevant documents retrieved by our algorithm (true positives) divided by the total number of retrieved documents (both true positives and false positives). The precision value is in the [0, 1] range. Recall is the number of relevant documents retrieved by our system (true positives) divided by the number of total correct documents in the corpus (both true positives and false negatives). The recall value is in the [0, 1] range. The F-measure is the average harmonic mean of two measures: precision and recall. The diversity measure is used for observing the sections of each sentence. The diversity value is also in the [0, 1] range. If the diversity value is high, this means that several sections are used in the court decision process. Generally, there are many methods for calculating the diversity value; the Jaccard measure is chosen for investigating the diversity performance of ATOB.

The top 30 legal sentences retrieved by ATOB using different setups are evaluated to compare with the Baseline method. All experimental findings values are shown in Table 12. We found that set F has the best precision, recall and F-measure values, whereas the best diversity value is obtained from set A. Notice that sets A, B, E and F give high performance in terms of precision, recall, F-measure and diversity because these four experiments apply the ant colony algorithm. Against the Baseline, we found that sets C, D, G and H give poor performance because they are without the ant colony algorithm. Nonetheless, sets A and F have no significantly different performance. The disadvantage of set F is the manual seed ontology construction and the non-stop automatic ontology expansion process – set F needs more processing time and the user needs to do manual seed ontology construction. We conclude that set A is the most suitable experimental setup for ATOB which consists of automatic seed ontology construction, weighted ontology using the ant colony algorithm and an automatic stop for the ontology expansion process.

caption.p: Overall performance

sec.p: In order to investigate the efficiency of the seed ontology used in the ATOB, we compare two methods for the seed ontology constructing: Automatic and Manual (see Table 13 for detail). The performances obtained from the Automatic seed ontology construction are calculated from the average performance of set A, B, C and D, whereas the performances obtained from the Manual seed ontology construction are calculated from the average performance of sets E, F, G and H. We found that the performance of Baseline is worse than those of ATOB algorithms. For the seed ontology, we found that using automatical seed ontology construction outperforms manual ontology construction in terms of diversity. Note that the precision, recall and F-measure of these two setups are not significantly different.

caption.p: Average of precision, recall, F-measure and diversity for comparison

sec.p: Surprisingly, the empirical results demonstrate that the ant colony algorithm greatly affects the retrieval process. We investigate the ant colony efficiency embedded in our weighted ontology using two methods: With ant and Without ant. The With ant value is obtained from the average performance of set A, B, E and F, whereas the Without ant method is the average performance from the set C, D, G and H. The results show that the ant colony algorithm applied for weighted ontology greatly affects the four measured parameters of the Baseline and the Without ant method. We conclude that the effective ontology should be weight-embedded.

Moreover, we investigate the retrieval performance using the ontology obtained from the ATOB system. We set up two methods for ontology construction: the Automatic-stop ontology expansion method and the Non-automatic-stop ontology expansion method. The value of the Automatic-stop ontology expansion method calculated from the average measured value of set A, C, E and G using the threshold is equal to 0.8, whereas the Non-automatic-stop ontology expansion method is the average measured value from the experimental set B, D, F and H using a threshold of 1.0 – the first-level child nodes of the keyword are completed. Conversely, the performances of the Automatic-stop ontology expansion method and the Non-automatic-stop ontology expansion method are not significantly different. The Automatic-stop ontology expansion method is more efficient than the Non-automatic-stop method with regard to the convergence speed, conciseness of ontology size and total processing time.
Figure 7 shows an example of appropriate ontology created by set A of the ATOB algorithm. This ontology consists of 121 nodes and 649 links.

caption.p: Example of ontology created by ATOB algorithm.

sec.title: 5. Conclusions
sec.p: In this work, we have studied the impact of different methods for the construction of seed ontology: weighted ontology and the ontology expansion process. We propose a new framework called ATOB that consists of three main modules: automatic seed ontology building, legal document retrieval and the legal ontology expansion module. Interestingly, the main advantage of the ATOB framework is that all performances of the ATOB algorithm are better than for the Baseline method. The empirical results demonstrate that the most suitable ATOB framework consists of the seed ontology constructed automatically by ATOB. Moreover, ATOB applies the ant colony algorithm as a mechanism to perform weight updating in terms of a weighted ontology. We find that the ant colony significantly improves the court sentences retrieval process. We also conclude that the ontology should be weight-embedded. Furthermore, the automatic-stop ontology expansion using a threshold parameter has sufficient performance to terminate the ontology expansion. In addition, the ATOB algorithm provides suitable ontology size, speed and total processing time. The precision, recall, F-measure and diversity values are 0.90, 0.91, 0.90 and 0.39, respectively.
We plan to extend our work in the near future to other areas of Thai law, and to investigate other techniques for the improvement of ontology and legal information retrieval.
